0CkOtB2i8Xx5B9Nk6_VHKw.text: This is based a few yards away from the more popular Shezan restaurant. The food is ok and the seating is a little cramped. Prices are quite high and you may prefer to pay a little extra but get the satisfaction that you would get from Shezan instead. I would however recommend the fish for a starter as it was very unique and vert tasty that i actually ordered more. Other than that it is a place worth trying once i guess.

GjjdfbH57CsuOtktdaAWdA.text: I would rather have Saffron in LA than this anyway.  Slow service, mediocre-low quality food, and expensive.  50 pounds for 2 entrees, side of rice, and veggie rolls.  Skip it.

JVu0aF7fnlaoCBWaD4MEtQ.text: A good Indian find in the heart of Knightsbridge.I had wanted British Indian food to impress, and it certainly hasn't disppointed. The lamb vindaloo looked attractive to me at first, but its 3-star spicy rating was enough to deter. I love spicy food but certainly wasn't prepared to suffer the consequences of that on this trip. Instead we went with the saam lamb. Fantasticly thick blended spicy spinach with cubed lamb perfect for a garlic naan pairing.The tandoori chicken was a bit on the dry side.  Its meat also was leaner, unlike the factory farm product you'd expect back in the States. Poultry is always tricky, and fattier chickens appear to make for more forgiving outcomes.For the rice we went with the onion rice pulao. What the menu fails to mention is that it's in fact basmati rice stir fried with diced tomatos and perilla seeds. So very fragrant, so very understated.The wait service was adequate and prompt despite it being staffed with only one waiter and a bus boy.Also let it be known that they have Kingfisher on tap; that alone counts for two stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom. Garlic naan, tandoori chicken, saam lamb and  onion rice pulao

aTaQ8rXJdC061QQjksW8Bg.text: I used to really like this place and have been countless times since 2011. The food was really good, the prices used to be reasonable, and the service was OK too.However, on my last visit I brought some friends and found that the prices have gone up noticeably by a few pounds -- but the quality or quantity has not improved. They also add a service charge of 12.50% onto the bill, but the quality of service has, rather ironically, gotten worse.Also, as we were leaving, there was an unpleasant situation where the waiter informed us that we were about £1.50 short. While we had paid for the whole meal and left ample tip (optional), my friend paid the difference anyway. (I later calculated using card payment receipts and we were only £0.50 short.) I thought it was a very unnecessary confrontation. In any case, I didn't expect a restaurant in Knightsbridge to be so stingy, especially after I had recommended and introduced the place to a group of friends. Sad to admit that I'm not sure if I'll return.

yycjhi2M4l0S87GsxVD0Pw.text: Yummy! We stopped in after *window* shopping at Harrods. The pappadum was great, as were the meat samosas! Wish we had something like this at home!

7hIW_I_F2tq_PDumGDq8Lg.text: We stopped with our kids for lunch based on the Yelp reviews. As visitors to London we knew we would never be there again. Unfortunately so did the staff and they treated us accordingly. The prices were obscene and they added a gratuity to the bill automatically for a group of 4. The service was was worse than indifferent, it bordered on deliberately rude. The food however was good. It was our most expensive meal in London and also the worst.

UhIiNbc7NkKTTiVsg7kIXg.text: Good honest Indian.  Clean. Well maintained. Friendly service. Rich curries like I like. Meats in curries could be a little more tender.

b4WmkRvHswhM-06_ex_EBA.text: What the hell just happened?  So many good yelp reviews for Haandi, how was my meal so bland?  oh dear god... blaaaaaaaaaandI don't even see any point in commenting on the unhelpful staff or the preposterous music (yes.  preposterous, that isn't just some 12 character type, the music really was that notably bad).  I'm just so bummed right now.  I came after having skipped lunch so I was starving and the yelp reviews had me really looking forward to haandi.  Instead I couldn't even finish my food.  I've had comparable indian food served at the cafeteria in Canary Wharf where I'm working.Man I hate writing negative yelp reviews.  I'm so mad at you right now Haandi, why weren't you better???

VCjd87778Ej9qlCkQcVxDA.text: The main reason for the 2 stars is the service. It took forever to get our food (and they mixed up part of our order anyway) and our waiter was terrible. He seemed annoyed when we didnt know what we wanted to order 4 minutes after walking into the restaurant. After ordering, he came around to tell us our food was running late. That was the last time we saw him. He didn't bring us our food (food runners did) and never came by our table to ask how the food was (he was there the whole time, just never came to our table). We had to get up and go to the front of the restaurant to ask for our check, which took them over 10 min to bring. The food was decent but not special at all, and VERY overpriced in my opinion. (Ex. £14.50 for chicken tikka masala that came in a small bowl and did not include rice.) Maybe they were having an off night, but I would not come here again.

LuoMbmn4zlsXKs83q6_ENA.text: I really, really liked it here! Everything was delicious. The vindaloo was properly spicy. I ordered black lentils in a creamy sauce, which I've never seen on an Indian menu, and they were sooo rich and good. The bread was lovely and puffy and the samosas the best kind of crispy, in that very thin pastry. Excellent array of curries, with many options for vegetarians (and an egg curry for "eggytarians"). Prices a little more than I'd pay on a regular basis though, but ok for a night out.

YBJAGI92gxmFiqtx9q9Tcg.text: This was a very satisfying meal.  I've eaten Indian food in many countries and the food was authentic.  The flavors were good and the restaurant was fairly friendly to family with children (as we were a 2+2). The service was good for European standards as well.  The only drawback was the price - recognizing this is one of the most expensive neighborhoods in London, we sort of expected to pay 60 Gbp for dinner (no alcohol).  Price kept us from trying what would ordinarily be a handful of different lesser-expensive side dishes. Recommendation is to portion the menu to allow for more sampling a of smaller dishes- perhaps pair-up some of the side dishes or offer "choice of 2" options.  The food was great but would have liked to go a little deeper in the menu.

_ElTV5D3NfcxZWqcsDGegg.text: Haandi is a great Indian restaurant. Arrived from LA this afternoon and joined my friends here for dinner. I really enjoyed the tender chunks of lamb I. Their Roganjosh and the  fish tikka masala was very good. The Anna's, Paranthropus and roti were all very well made. However although the food was good it lacked the WOW factor. That's why it's only getting 3 not. 4 stars.

PJZd6P3pvMdptiiuKck5LQ.text: Love it. This has to be the best Indian restaurant I ever went to.  Too bad they don't have one in New York City, because I'm sure they're make good money.

r-ERwCu9XhMaw-u7yY2mfw.text: The nondescript facade doesn't prepare you for the bright, sleek interior of this outstanding Indian restaurant, where the busy kitchen staff is on view behind a wall of curved tinted glass.Lamb lovers have several choices, the best of which are the spicy minced lamb with fresh peas, onions, tomatoes, and chillies and the lamb vindaloo with fresh coconut milk. I also recommend the potato and cauliflower stir fry flavored with ginger, baked eggplant mashed with onions and tomatoes, and fresh tuna curry. There's a wide assortment of stuffed naans; my favorite is one topped with chopped nuts, cheese, tomato sauce, and coriander. For dessert be sure to try the delicious carrot pudding with almonds, which is something I haven't found on other Indian menus.The waiters are very friendly and attentive, and the chef is happy to spice according to a diner's request, so if you ask for medium heat that's exactly what you'll get.This Knightsbridge dining spot is worth a trip from anywhere in the city. Because it's very popular, even midweek, reservations are recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom

xYjEvOaG7uWMJz_SgiM1AA.text: Wow, apparently I went to an entirely different restaurant than the other reviewer....Craving Indian food, we forgo-ed going to a traditional hole in the wall curry stand in favor of a more high class establishment. By the end of this meal I was wishing we hadn't come.Our server did NOT like us, he barely looked at us, and he didn't even ask us how everything was. Now...I am certainly used to how nonchalant service is in Indian restaurants...but this was ridiculous!! The same server who couldn't give a crap about what we wanted or liked was fawning over another group of ladies near by.I went with the Murg Kesari Korma plus an order of Naan. Coming in at over £10 I expected a lot from this dish. Well, I was sorely disappointed. Rice does NOT come with any of the dishes and it costs an extra £3!! What?! Never have I ever had to order rice with a dish, and believe me, I go to a lot of Indian restaurants. My chicken dish was flavorless, I couldn't taste any saffron or almonds, and it wasn't spicy in the least (I asked for medium). The only saving grace about the whole dish was that there was a lot of chicken included. The Naan was too crispy and I was only glad to get it because of the absence of the rice.So, in conclusion: - Too expensive, bland food, rude service, disappointment all around. I wish we had found a hole-in-the-wall place instead.

z2eQU54X46DSUZU4W3gnag.text: When i worked in the area we used to go a couple times a week for indian food and a few king fishers.Great lamb chops ... tasty vindaloo.

N6bxPWo8Cb8dNr5F1CJ2Lw.text: Excellent neighborhood Indian restaurant that we walked to from the Mandarin Oriental Hotel.  This is true British Indian food.

kA9uGTeXOlyQftiLDMgwTQ.text: Firstly, regarding the service that some people complain about - whilst I've heard that there is one slightly surly staff member who can be a bit difficult (and I daresay, perhaps he is the source of grievances in these reviews), the others are fantastic. Of particular note is the exceedingly friendly Kenyan chap who normally serves me - always cheery, efficient and attentive. As with many restaurants, I reckon it's a case of you get what you put in - be polite and friendly, and you'll usually receive that in return. Either way, the service has never been anything other than solid at worst and excellent at best.Wine and beer list is well thought-out with some interesting selections including a red sourced from India which was definitely worth a try. Usual Indian beers available, plus Tusker, which is a very light and refreshing African offering.On to the food. One word - sublime. I've bought, variously from my South Asian friends, Tamils, Kenyans, Punjabis and Gujuratis, all of whom have had nothing but praise for the standard and authenticity of the cooking. Tandoori is perfectly cooked - succulent and well spiced. Poppadums and assorted chutneys are excellent, the mint sauce being one of the best I've had the pleasure of trying - not too confected or overly-minted, just right. Curries are superb - wonderful heat from the vindaloo, good quality meats used throughout and clearly not just a case of chucking in a bit of tandoori chicken in to a heated sauce. Dhaba chicken and black lentils are exceptionally good and an absolute must. Rice is spot-on with the correct texture and level of moisture. Naan breads are very good - properly cooked with ghee. Their version of peshwari, with a sweetened tomato top (and no sultanas/raisins) is a departure from the bog standard naan and is definitely worth a try, as is the wonderfully flavoursome garlic naan.Desserts are fairly good - nothing major to write home about, but solid and well-executed, if not as rapture-inducing as the starters and mains.All in all, arguably one of the best non-haute cuisine Indians in London. Sure, it's a little pricier than a take-away (hey - this is Knightsbridge!), and it has no aspirations to be the Cinnamon Club, but it does what it sets out to wonderfully - top notch Punjabi curries and tandoori in a relaxed atmosphere.

e7Nc7A15tz28ZWmk9FY0cw.text: I've been to this place a few times I found the staff to be pleasant however a little bit slow, the food is ok but I've had better. I think Indian food in this country has lost something over the last few year and this resturant is proof of that.

Zch36I-HLOXG6YJdYYseXA.text: This is not the place to go if you want elegant service OR an inexpensive Indian meal. However, the food is very good. The chicken tikka is great and the cheese nan is the best I've ever had. Chicken korma was disappointing, but that's about it. A month ago, the waiter only had three menus for our group of four, but he removed the service charge. Tonight, he was talking on his cell phone while delivering a glass bottle of sparkling water to me. The bottle slipped out of his hand and bowled over the glasses on my table. Luckily, nothing broke. He was shaken, but I was actually a bit amused and got a free (woo hoo I saved 1 pound!) papadam.

gw4PguOMuHJAFpSjMO-cow.text: Andy Hayler loves this place. Given that I learned about the Sportsman from him - and that the Sportsman may be the finest restaurant the world has ever seen - I was expecting something great. But it isn't great and it isn't cheap. It's mediocre and the portions are small. Lamb curry on the bone was mostly bone; the aloo gobi was fine but a poor value. Other curries are tolerable but nothing special. Given the wretched level of most Indian cooking in central London I suppose Haandi is a good choice. But really, a trip to West Ham is a much better idea.

aQSfJ05Af_84czB14nlshg.text: Mediocre food,  bad service that takes forever.  I ordered my food and waited for a LONG time.  When I asked about it,  the waiter (who,  apparently was also the Manger) said "every one is very busy". Great response to a customer. Even my check took more than 30 minutes to be delivered.  And they added 30% service charge to the bill!  The nerve! Well never visit this place again. Absolutely the worst experience!

IBs_pL1miq9YK-EtYxL9GA.text: Came here after touring the Victoria & Albert museum, which was a short walk away. We shared the aloo chaat, hubby had the palak paneer, and I had some sort of masala curry. Nice sized portions, with extra charges for naan and any rice. Overall good food.

dukDXFlZAXNoegn5ORUbKw.text: Excellent Indian food - probably the best bhindi bhaji I have had in London. The curries are great, the lamb is succulent and I've heard the mint tea is divine. On top of this the servers are jovial and they serve Indian beer!I keep coming back :)

_O8j7tb8URNEg7F-Xtt6hA.text: When my family reunited in London we met for a late dinner at Haandi. I know it was late because my sister-in-law and I didn't get back from Harry Potter Studios (yelp.com/biz/harry-potte…) until close to 10. There were ten of us meeting up; I'm sure the restaurant staff had no idea what was about to descend upon their quiet little establishment. We ordered a few appetizers for the table. Several plates of naan (garlic & plain) and multiple dishes for everyone to share. Many of us ordered based on what the waiter recommended which was the right way to go, but it unfortunately means I have no idea what we actually had. A couple curries, lamb, prawns, chicken. Just a wide variety. It was all very good and I would definitely go back.Learned a new trick to ask for a bowl of yogurt. It makes everything creamy, cools down the spice and just adds a nice layer of flavor to the dish. While it may not be a 'new' trick, it was new to me.

V2rVPp0V_o_tpz51Mm4bog.text: Very ok food not authentic Indian food. Was flavorless I had to use the condiments to add some flavor to the food. I was asked if I needed some hot sauce to add to the food all I needed was some flavor!! I tried the chicken tikka masala, chili chili fish, mango lassi (terrible, made from concentrate) and the garlic naan (was alright).

PSf8spORl7ivCw3xluV0Aw.text: Amazing Indian Food! I had the most amazing palak paneer.  That food tasted authentic and home cooked.  The service was a tad slow besides that no complaints.

87JbwrOmDkspaU03WFNMUw.text: Great little casual spot. Locals and tourists a like. The wine list is limited, but the food menu is extensive at reasonable prices. The service was good - my husband and I have limited knowledge of Indian food and our waiter made great suggestions for us.  We enjoyed each dish he recommended. I will warn to be careful of the heat level when ordering - medium is quite spicy!  Lastly, as a vegetarian, they offered many selections. Overall good experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom

7Y9SLgW6AgqvCRfQy1tbyQ.text: Really good food! We've always heard London has great Indian food, but both my (Indian) husband and I have struggled to find Indian here that's not super high-end or very low-end, this was the perfect middle ground! We went here on the last night of our honeymoon, while stopping in London for the night on our way back to LA from Sicily. After a week of pizza and pasta, we were ready to go heavy on the vegetables! We didn't want a super-fancy, tasting menu type place for Indian (in fact, we feel like Indian is almost always better not fancy), but also didn't want a buffet or Chipotle-style Indian, which seems to be catching on in popularity. This place totally fit the bill - a convenient and beautiful 12 or so minute walk from our hotel, warm and smelled delicious as soon as we entered. After a longer than expected flight from Italy, getting through customs, checking into our hotel and getting here close to 9pm, we were hungry!With the help of some friendly and quick service, we ordered subzi jalfrezi (masala of mixed vegetables), bhindi masala (okra, onions, masala), dal tadka (yellow lentils with onion, chilis), mint naan and peshwari (sweet) naan. Truly, everything was delicious and a good serving size without being overwhelmingly large. The mixed vegetables was a great mix of carrots, green beans, cauliflower and if any, maybe one or two potatoes, a nice mix-up from the usual potato-heavy veggie dishes at Indian restaurants. The okra was fabulous, perfectly sauteed and a nice bite to it. The dal was a bit on the spicy side for me (a massive chili pepper was in it), but still very comforting and filling. Something about all of the spices in Indian food makes it that much more satisfying. The naans were hearty and well-spiced. I've enjoyed other sweet naans in the past with raisins, currants, nuts, etc., whereas this more felt like a cinnamon-sugar naan, but still sweet and delicious - no extra dessert needed!Of note, they also had an extensive drinks and cocktail menu that was reasonably priced, even including some creative-looking cocktails! They also have a few restaurants in Africa, and it seemed there was definitely some influence from that as well. This place reminded us a lot of one of our favorite Indian restaurants in NYC, Chola. Next time we're in London, we'd definitely go back!

EIP1XL5PwI8OzpZpWu-UjQ.text: Memorable North Indian food.  I will never forget their Gagar Halwa, grated carrot, spiced sweet pudding.

qesPPqE915Wj5J1HevyvNQ.text: When in London, this is a must!    Conveniently located on Cheval Place, on a side Street in close proximity to Harrod's.    Very good and consistent food!  Probably our favourite Indian restaurant worldwide,  we have been to hundreds of Indian eateries.    They curries are excellent, their Jumbo Prawn appetizer is out of this world and their Tandoori is always hot, sizzling and tender straight from the kitchen.  Also, full bar and has capacity to house parties in a secluded room for those who seek a private area.

eycTZHNxn7Q8Vkj3gKn4kg.text: We are here on our last night in London. The two entrances was a little confusing but they were very welcoming when we went inside. The food was delicious- we got Chicken Tikka Masala and Aloo Gobi with rice and naan. The spice was perfect for us and the naan was especially good. The staff was friendly and they seemed really accommodating to the large birthday celebration also in the restaurant. There was also a window to the kitchen, which we thought was neat.

_0JfS0pvJaavTuC8GEtMWw.text: My husband and I are visiting London and wanted to try some desi food! I looked at so many places but color and texture wise in pics this looked most appealing. We went yday, a Saturday night and it was packed! Couple of families there. It was very hot in there and there was no air flow at all considering it's been cooler during our September stay. Our food took some time to come out. In fact about five tables food came out same time as ours, and two guys waited over 35mins for their food. We had aloo CHaat which was a sour lemon vinegar taste but was so good! I'm always so skeptical of kabab and other non chicken meat...we live in Chicago and have great places there and I still don't eat there. Getting the lamb seekh Kabab is a must. Color inside was completely done and it was edible for me! The flavors of that Kabab were amazing! Good amount bc it was just me and my hubby. And we also had the chicken tikka masala. Meat quality was amazing, but food was warm and on the cold side unlike other two dishes. Not that those were hot either. I thought it was be spicy or taste little different since its tikka masala but it was like putting tomatoes into my mouth. Still got through eating it since it was good. At the end when u ask for ur check...you get magic towels and the waitress poured hot water on it and they became hand sized towels to wash ur hands. U get a haandi mint afterwards which is just like the Olive Garden candy you get back in the states. My husband loved all the food whereas I wish food was hotter and tikka masala didn't taste like I was putting tomato in my mouth. They have alcohol. And I order Coke, it came in the glass bottle with a glass and ice. Enjoy!

AIcaYIfytxaVSuKKeTt-4Q.text: In short: I loved the food but did not really feel an Indian vibe inside.Coming in Haandi was a great opportunity for me to revisit my long-forgotten love to Indian food and it's spicy dishes. We were greeted nicely and put to our table almost immediately. I liked that the staff knew their place and I didn't have to beckon them through the whole evening. The waiter knew when he was needed and also understood the food in a way to explain it to a simple non-indian foodie like me. The meals were great, came out quickly but we didn't felt rushed to leave. It was all really delicious and the whole party was well full on curry-spiced bits of heaven. The only thing that put me off and made me lower my rating was the crammed feel of the whole restaurant and a tad too-ordinary choices in pots and plates.However, I might have been too stressed that night so anything would have irritated me and it should not divert you from visiting Haandi.

NTEBoBo6x7XLSpXbK8RFuQ.text: Pretty much a standard Indian curry. It was nice, but nothing special. I had the Tikka Masala, while my friend has the Fish Curry. I give it 3 stars because, it didn't taste much different to takeaway curries I get quite often, and it's triple the price. There was nothing that really made me go "MMMM!". The host/waiter's service was good.

Sr0WoouoSpKPeTdzKu28OA.text: Now, being Indian, for me, indian food has to be something special when I'm paying for it, unless its a 'curry house', (and there is a difference), in which case, I expect milder food and loads of cream, like when i used to go out with my mates as a teenager! However, when you're at a restaurant in Knightsbridge, you would expect something of a higher quality.Came here on a 'double date', after a yelp event no less. The service was pretty good, our guy being really friendly, chatty and nice, despite us being a little noisy (that'll be free wine at the aforementioned event!) (which is kinda why I've gone up to 4 stars). Food was ok, my wife liked the Egg curry, though I thought my saag lamb was a bit lacking in lamb. in hindsight, perhaps I should have gone for the more traditionally spicy dishes. I thought the sundries (yoghurt, naans, rice) were quite good though(the other reason for 4 stars).

axpqeiWbrCx0a8YOLGBgsA.text: Lunch today was exceptional - as always! Fred is the perfect host - gracious, smiling, warm and hospitable. Best Indian food in England. As good as Nairobi. Please open in New York City!

KtLBMVa-ZRLbR-NEJkr1yA.text: We went to Haandi in a group of 4. It was my friend's suggestion who works at Harrods across the street. The place is casual and the ambiance is average. The most positive part is its food. Try Chicken Tika Masala and Lamb Vindaloo.

66LguV4Se0Iiy2ceuTLn1g.text: Great little place we found across from Harrods. the food was scrumptious.   My wife who is not a big Indian cuisine person loved the chicken Tikka Masala.  I had a very spicy chicken dish (forgot the name ) that was delicious. Naan was fantastic.   Relatively expensive.

gZwiUp5VxdmbKLnUooBpzg.text: Looking for some quality Indian Cuisine among the infinite options in London? Look no further friend, for Haandi has come to the rescue.Star 1 - How was the service and atmosphere?Tucked away to the point where you'll likely miss it upon first pass, Haandi provides an extremely comfortable dining atmosphere whether you're in for a drink and quite bite after work or are just out with some family or friends.  With extremely friendly service complimenting an array of table sizes that can easily accommodate any party, I was thoroughly impressed with Haandi even before sitting down.  To top it off, my party of three were served in under 15 minutes. Star Granted.Star 2 - How were the portions relative to the cost?For around £12 - £15 each, my party of three opted to go with a combination of garlic na'an, two large portions of white rice, and two large dishes of tikka masala and lamb vindaloo to share between us.  While £30+ may seem like a lot, the portions we were served were absolutely massive, and at the end of the meal we were all so stuffed that arguments ensued over who would have the task of finishing the rice! Excellent Value. Star Granted.Stars 3/4 - How was the food?Since I've now been back in United States for several months after leaving London, I can honestly say that I dream of my meal at Haandi.  With each dish customizable as to how spicy you want it, I was absolutely blown away by both the quantity and diversity of flavors that were in both the Chicken Tikka Masala and the spicy Lamb Vindaloo.  Additionally, the Garlic Na'an was absolutely brilliant.  Without a doubt in my mind, Haandi dished up some of the best Indian cuisine that I've ever had. Dual Stars Granted.Star 5 - Would you eat it every day if you could?Yes, yes and yes.  Regardless of whether you're new to Indian food or a seasoned vet, Haandi is worth a visit regardless of how long you're staying or living in London. I would personally pay for the owner's airfare if he or she were willing to come and open a Los Angeles location. Star Granted.

JBpUvuGDnWwAAS3HqYfn0A.text: staff were excellent and food was very authentic and not too spicy. There is also a good vegetarian selection which is good as so many restaurants seem to forget when you go to a restaurant that someone you are going with may be vegetarian and also as a meat eater I also like to have a choice in vegitarian dishes. I would have given a higher rating but the chicken was a little rubbery so had to mark down for that. I could see the restaurant is popular with large groups also booking and it is located very close to Knightsbridge tube as well.

fOGPcuOs-qcl1RgUX0Bz3Q.text: OMG! The best indian food in the city. Just a 5 mins walk from Harrods. The goan fish curry is an absolute must order, fish is tender and perfectly cooked! If you like spicy, tell them to make it spicier because 2 stars doesn't tickle at all. Naan is made to order and you can see the chefs preparing it through the open kitchen. Meat samosas are so good, you can really taste the lamb (although it could have been salted a little more.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom

OGfbgax6KnB0FrdjdxecJw.text: If you're looking for a classy Indian restaurant in Knightsbridge then this place would be it, but otherwise,​ I wouldn't recommend.London is known for their food and diversity, everywhere I have dined in London was nothing less than a phenomenal experience except this place. We walked in after a long day of walking around in Knightsbridge​ and Harrods, given the restaurant was only half full, we weren't even acknowledged to get seated until after some time. After we got seated there were no server, no water or silverware until again much later, seemed like any other short-staffed​ Indian/Asia​n restaurant to keep a business running.What we had:-Jeera Chicken-Chicken Tikka-Hariyali Kabab (no green chutney..)-Garlic naanI'm a big foodie and if the food is good I don't think twice before splurging but I've had so much better than this Indian​ food honestly, food quantity was very poor for the price they ask for some average Indian​ food and terrible customer service where they barely ever check up on you and takes forever to come when you call someone. Beautiful decor though, but that's​ just about it.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom

lJjD0Kxt-H8WLp0MDmYK0A.text: This was our first meal in London. It really hit the spot! This restaurant is definitely upscale Indian. There are lots of options to choose from - many dishes not like ones you'd find in most Indian restaurants in the States - and they served up a great flavor. Each of our dishes was unique, and it was hard to pick a favorite.This was a nice spot to go with my parents. There seemed to be a lot of couples but also big groups dining here.Go for the Kingfisher on draft!Our waiters were very nice and just the right amount of attentive.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom. Delicious dinner
Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom. Hours

H30IZkWeZtObUJ-b8_mlgA.text: Had lunch at Haandi with friends last week...Service is very friendly and food came out quickly.Ambiance is nice enough, but the decor seemed a bit dated. The place was busy for a Monday afternoon.Food was good for the most part. - Shrimp was poor quality, I wouldn't order this again.- Dal Tadka was good.- Aloo Gobi was good.- Peas Pulao was good.- Naan received rave reviews (I didn't try this).Prices are higher than they should be, could be the proximity to Harrods though. Based on price alone I probably won't return but the food was good enough to give Haandi 4 stars.

mskiQmYbj1LoT1GR_v1f2w.text: This restaurant is classy but their service is not good. We waited a long time after going to the restaurant but nobody even served us even water. Foods are pricy & quantity is very less.

OTnHhaaaTjBgdiXnGwdzTA.text: Overrated. Food is below average. Do not order Dum aloo or Masala onion rice. I'm too polite to give it 1 star. Let's leave it at that.Oh, I felt that the male waiter is clueless and a bit rude.

eFZE8ENWWmMYTejyx6YoaQ.text: The restaurant is nicely decorated and clean. The stuff is quite  friendly and in the menue there are enough different indian dishes. So we chose a little starter, vegan kofta and minced meat lamb.Generelly the food was ok, but that's it. The lamb was prepared without any sauce and so it was a very dry pleasure.The taste of the kofta was neutral - nothing special. We paid almost 70 pounds inc. drinks for averaging dishes - really overpriced.So I would not recommend this restaurant to any friend!

sYSpKrYVZlkVcpA-kUhGXQ.text: Haandi is a tasty restaurant with a layed back comfortable atmosphere and friendly staff.

xrrK_28NRa7-bs1ijlU2Jg.text: This is my favorite Indian restaurant in the world.  Every time I have been here, the service is impeccable and the food is amazing.  Tandoori Chicken, Chicken Tikka Masala, the naan bread, it's all first rate.

sop7QB4YeOLfOqrbo7pllw.text: The food was really good (I ordered a vegan eggplant dish) but the service wasn't so great. My friends enjoyed their dishes as well (a lentil stew and a chicken curry) however the food took forever to arrive. There weren't even that many people at all but there was no explanation as to why the food took SO long.Also, the waiter wasn't very accommodating when I asked about vegan options. He was also not very understanding when I made a few requests about my food. Considering the service and how the food wasn't amazing, the place was quite overpriced. If you're in the area and craving Indian food, Haandi is a good option but otherwise, it's nothing that special.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom. Punjabi aloo baigan with jasmine rice

CG19jDO-SNBSkYkupY4Iiw.text: This is a very good rual Indian. We had lamb pepper fryed, aubergine and chicken chennai something.. I would recommend it to everybody who likes Indian. Nothing fancy but really good. I will come back for sure.

i3P035byMYqC-Pw8UyzacQ.text: Expensive and not good food. Don't waste your money, I ordered a spice lamb dish and the waiter want me to order their 5 pounds little dish of white rice, then when I got my food I realized why you need that little dish of rice, the lamb was terribly spice and the amount of rice they give isn't enough to go with the dish, so get ready to pay 10 pounds for a decent portion of rice. They should stop being so cheap and include rice on all their dishes since the food is already so pricey.

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom. The decor is tropical and the room is big and spacious

ENTFqAyZL1E2-KqPwj2QpQ.text: Entering the restaurant from Brompton Road, which is a very discrete entrance for a restaurant of this caliber, sets very low expectations. It feels like it will be yet another basement restaurant, but that's where I was mistaken.The food is superb and the waiting staff is friendly and competent; for instance very helpful when asked allergy questions - they made sure there was no way I could consume any nuts.The ambience at the restaurant is charming with Indian music playing over the speakers in the ceiling, and, as always, when natives eat at ethnic restaurants, you know the food is good!

wEavQYCgHtk_t2ixzQCuZQ.text: Wonderful Indian food. I had the palaak paneer and even as a devout carnivore am now dreaming of spinach. The cheese even tasted house made. Attentive service and always interesting clientele...

49Ke9ZPiH4Y7-Eo0gzcBbw.text: Food was good. A bit spicy and they couldn't customize for people who can't take what they make. Daal , fish tikka and chicken curry were good but roomali roti was too tough and dry. Most worrying though was service. Waiters had no idea of ingredients for allergy information! Everyone had a different answer and finally the head chef said he can't vouch for any food to be allergen free. We almost walked out! By luck, a manager from restaurant who was in a personal dinner with family overheard us and intervened to have customized food made for us. We will not visit again.

rbjh4QhAujtysNHvTOAKsg.text: Checked out this Indian Restaurant in the Knightsbridge area on my recent visit to London.  We came based on recommendations from some locals and they did not steer us wrong.  Overall the food was amazing from the samosas to the Chicken Tikka Masala.  Everything we sampled was very tasty and it was a treat to be able to see one of the chefs actually making the chicken and naan in the tandoor ovens.  My only grip and what kept this review from being a 5 star was that service was a bit slow and at times we were left waiting for water or someone to come around to take our order or get the check.

Ewaungajcb6ieBPaVApyCg.text: My husband and I were looking for a cheaper Indian food option and thought this might work. Nope. The food was just ok... I ordered the chicken tikka masala and my husband had the lamb biriyani. I've had MUCH better Indian food. In fact, there's a gas station back in the States just down from where I work that serves better Indian foodat about $20 for both of us. My husband asked for a little bowl of masala sauce on the side and they charged us £5 for it! Ridiculous. We were seated before a table of 7 and a table of 4. Somehow our order was taken after theirs, putting our food preparation behind them as well. Our drinks were absolutely terrible, pretty sure mine was just an orange juice actually. Overall, not impressed that two people couldn't eat in here for less £80. For the money, the Red Fort in Soho is a MUCH better option.

Dd9efeD3yMmCB7cKOSHbDw.text: Pricey but good. Family friendly including a generously sized 10£ kids plate that our 3 yo and 5 yo were able to share (tomato, cucumber, chips & tandoori chicken). Chicken Tikka Masala, Saag Aloo, Samosa (small, 5 pieces), Aloo Gobi and Jasmine Rice. Smaller portions but tastey.

5UYmkLmU75JkF9SgI3NyoA.text: Has a very bad case of "Indian restaurant syndrome" whereas the staff are under the mistaken belief that  their restaurant is fancy. Consequently, the service, while not bad, is a bit uppity; the manager in  particular suffers from delusional self importance. The decor reinforces just how far this restaurant has succumbed to IRS. I can excuse the palm trees, but a glass enclosed kitchen to watch cooks prepare standard curry is a bit too far, these poor guys have lost the plot.The curry, however, is very good in a very British way, which is obviously the best way to enjoy it - chicken was meant to swim in a buttery tomato concoction. Great fluffy naan, nice not too spicy vindaloo, and Cobra on tap - I'm sold.Maybe if I had made a reservation getting a table wouldn't have incited such emotion, but calling ahead to eat at a curry house? I just don't live my life that way.

0STKhU0GqipKnxsHO563Iw.text: O!M!G! Ok so everyone in the States has been telling me to eat the Indian food in London...I was skeptical. Then upon arriving here, the concierge at the Mandarin Oriental recommended some high end Indian place, but my doorman (whom I adore there) pointed me here - holy SH%% this place is good. The people are so sweet, and the food is just amazing. I ordered everything off the vegetarian menu, and the explosion of flavors sit very well on my palate! Try this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Haandi - London, United Kingdom. Dinner for 1
